Prophage

The Blog for Bacteria, Phages, Computers, and Science

Welcome to Prophage

Welcome to the Prophage blog 2.0! This is version 2.0 because it is a new location and structure of the original Prophage blog that started back in 2013. The old blog was very successful, with well over 100,000 views, but it was time to update the site.

This blog is written and maintained by Dr. Geoffrey Hannigan. Check out the latest blog entries below, navigate the site using the menu above, and check out the original Prophage here. Read more about Dr. Hannigan in the “about the author” section.

Latest Posts

  • Hippurate Microbiome Metabolite & Human Health May 31, 2021 Recent study uses human and animal systems biology to further understand the role of hippurate in health.
  • Motivating Science With MAP May 04, 2021 We can use Daniel Pink’s MAP criteria to motivate ourselves and our scientific environments.
  • Five Key Considerations When Building A Data Science Team November 01, 2020 Building a data science team is hard. Here we explore what may lead to success.
  • Learning To Code With Problem-Based Group Learning & LeetCode September 13, 2020 Our site recently got together to learn some Python through solving a problem.
  • Impact of Bacterial Viruses on Cancer Immunity August 29, 2020 Bacteriophage molecular mimicry impacts chemotherapy and immunotherapy efficacy.
  • Doing Group Science With The Agile Methodology September 02, 2019 Three helpful tips for managing large science projects using Agile/SCRUM.
  • Empowering Science Through Organization (Bullet Journals) June 16, 2019 Science demands organization, and that’s not easy. I’ve found the bullet journal approach to be really helpful.
  • Biosynthetic Potential of the Oral Microbiome in Dental Caries and Periodontitis April 21, 2019 A recently reported study outlines the biosynthetic functional potential of the oral microbiome.
  • Bacterial Small Molecules Provide Defense Against Their Viruses January 06, 2019 A recently published study outlines a chemical mechanism for phage infection defense in bacteria.
  • Recent Publication: The Colorectal Cancer Virome December 15, 2018 Our recent publication, as well as others, support a role for the gut virome (specifically bacteriophage) in colorectal cancer.
